text:
By Ben Rosario

The House of Representatives on Thursday, June 4, passed on third and final
reading the proposed Accelerated Recover and Investments Stimulus for the
Economy of the Philippines or ARISE Philippines Act that will earmark P1.31
trillion in a bid to jumpstart the economy that has been badly damaged by the
coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic.

Registering 216 affirmative and seven negative votes, congressmen demonstrated
strong support for the landmark measure that Speaker Alan Peter Cayetano and
the House leadership vigorously supported.

Nobody abstained from the voting that took place a day before Congress was set
to adjourn sine die.

Only about 25 House members were physically present at the Batasan Pambansa
plenary hall. The rest of the participants voted electronically.

Cayetano stressed that through the ARISE bill, the government will respond to
the needs of the workers in non-essential businesses, freelancers, repatriated
overseas Filipino workers (OFWs) and self-employed workers who may have been
left out in the DSWD's social amelioration programs and Small Business Wage
Subsidy Program.

On the other hand, Minority Leader and Manila Rep. Bienvenido Abante noted
some "imperfections" on the measure but pointed out the significance of having
it enacted.

The Makabayan bloc, composed of six party-list solons, thumbed down the
measure.

"Unfortunately, this stimulus bill actually reinforces the same, old economic
principles which have hobbled local industrial growth and agricultural
development, and that which made our public health system critically impaired
under the private sector's hands," said Gabriela Women's Party-list Rep.
Arlene Brosas in explaining her "no" vote.

Formerly known as the Philippine Economic Stimulus Act (PESA), HB 6815 affirms
the commitment of the "House of the People to pass this landmark measure that
may bring back life to the country's economy and mitigate effects of the
COVID-19 pandemic to our hardest hit businesses and sectors."

The bill was sponsored on the floor by Reps. Sharon Garin (AAMBIS Owa
Partylist), Joey Sarte Salceda (PDP-Laban, Albay), and Stella Luz Quimbo (LP,
Marikina City).

Garin, chairperson of the House Committee on Economic Reforms, said the whole
proposal - Transitional, Financial, Sectoral, and Structural - is the
immediate response to jumpstart the economy amid the pandemic.

Garin, who is also the co-chair of Subcommittee on Economic Response Package
Cluster of Defeat COVID-19 Committee, cited the urgency of passing the measure
that will offer immediate assistance to Filipinos who have lost jobs and other
means of livelihood as a result of the implementation of the enhanced
community quarantine in many areas in the country.

"Workers in non-essential businesses, the self-employed, the freelancers and
OFWs will be given a maximum subsidy of P15,000 per month for two (2) months,"
Garin said.

The bill will implement a wage subsidy program that will address the concerns
of the self-employed, freelancers, and so-called informal sector.

According to Cayetano around 865,000 workers from the film and entertainment
industry have been affected and the revenue loss to their sector is expected
to reach P100 billion this year.

The House leader said the "landmark measure" will also provide immediate
assistance to displaced workers and businesses including micro, small and
medium-scale enterprises (MSMEs) and accelerate investment to boost the
government's economic recovery plan.

Displaced workers and repatriated OFWs may also avail themselves of wage
subsidies amounting to at least 50% but not more than 75% of the P15,000,
which is the base amount of monthly salary prescribed in the bill.

Each qualified rank-and-file employee may avail himself or herself of a
monthly wage subsidy between P7,500 to P11,250 for two months.

The proposed allocation will also finance the enhanced Build, Build, Build
program that will improve healthcare, educational facilities, social housing
projects, digital infrastructure, creative industries and climate-smart and
resilient infrastructure and other related projects.

It also allocates P25 billion for the implementation of the Department of
Labor's TUPAD (Tulong Panghanapbuhay sa Ating Disadvantaged/Displaced Workers)
program to provide temporary employment to displaced workers.

The proposed economic stimulus budget for year 2020 is P568 billion. The
remainder, amounting to over P732 billion, will be budgeted for various
stimulus programs from 2021 until 2023.

CAPTION(S):

(MANILA BULLETIN FILE PHOTO)
